member.name: T:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo
member.summary: Instances of this class represent individual ASCII characters. Since the NUL character is defined, and occupies the first element, the numeric code that corresponds to a character maps directly to the corresponding element in this array.
member.example:
The ASCII code for a space is 32. ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo[32], for C#, or ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo(32), for Visual Basic, returns the item for the space character.
Likewise, the ASCII code for a horizontal TAB character is 9. Hence, the C# expression ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo[9] evaluates to the information about the TAB character. Likewise, ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo(9) does the same thing in Visual Basic.
The following example comes from production code in the class library that motivated me to create this library.
ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo [ ] asciiCharTbl = ASCII_Character_Display_Table.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AllASCIICharacters; StringBuilder sbTheBadChar = new StringBuilder ( ); sbTheBadChar.Append ( asciiCharTbl [ ( uint ) _chrBad ].DisplayText );
Obviously, more things go into the message before it is returned to the calling routine.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterType
member.summary: This enumeration maps the CharType strings to fast, efficient, safe integer values that correspond to three broad groups of characters.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterType.Undefined
member.summary: The value is uninitialized.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterType.NonPrintable
member.summary: The character is of a nonprintable type. Most of these are output device control codes.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterType.Printable
member.summary: These are the characters from which most text is composed.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterType.Extended
member.summary: These are the extended ASCII characters that have code points at or above 128, that require 8 bits to represent in binary coding.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype
member.summary: This enumeration maps the Subtype strings to fast, efficient, safe integer values that correspond to ten specialized groups of characters. These correspond roughly to the Unicode character categories.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.Undefined
member.summary: The value is uninitialized.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.NULL
member.summary: There is but one character in this subgroup, the ASCII NULL, sometimes called NUL, which has a numerical value of zero.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.Control
member.summary: These are the characters that have code point values between 1 and 31, most of which are device control characters that originally drove line printers.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.White_Space
member.summary: White space is another tiny subgroup; it contains five code points, 32, the everyday SPACE character, 160, the nonbreaking Space, 8, the destructive backspace, 9, the horizontal tab, and 11, the vertical tab, only one of which, the regular space, is considered printable. The nonbreaking space, also printable, is classified as an extended character because its code point is greater than 127, while the rest fall into the group that is comprised otherwise of device control codes. Since that is their primary function, they belong in this group.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.Punctuation
member.summary: Characters in this group are generally accepted as punctuation marks, of which one, the inverted question mark, belongs to the Extended group, owing to its high code point, 191.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.Symbol
member.summary: Characters in this group are a mixed bag of mathematical and other symbols.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.Numeral
member.summary: These characters represent the Arabic numerals zero through nine.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.UC_Latin_1_Letter
member.summary: Characters in this group represent the upper case letters of the Latin alphabet.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.LC_Latin_1_Letter
member.summary: Characters in this group represent the lower case letters of the Latin alphabet.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.Greek_Letter
member.summary: Only a handful of characters, all of which fall into the Extended group, are specifically identified as letters of the Greek alphabet. Others may have been overlooked. If you find one of them, please submit a pull request or open an issue.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype.Other_Letter
member.summary: This large group represents latters and joined characters used in other Western alphabets.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.#ctor
member.summary: This constructor satisfies interfaces that require a default constructor. It is marked private because the assembly that owns all instances of this class uses one of the other two constructors.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.#ctor(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Create an instance for a character for which the alternate display is undefined because it is either unnecessary or impractical.
member.param: The code is an unsigned integer between zero and 255.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.#ctor(System.UInt32,System.Char,WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterType,WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharacterSubtype,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: All instances of this class are created by calling this constructor.
member.param:
The code is an unsigned integer between zero and 255.
This argument receives the Code column from the embedded CSV file, which is stored and becomes the subscript (index) of an array.

This value is the Unicode representation of the character.
This argument receives the CHAR(n) column from the embedded CSV file.

This value is the CharacterType enumeration mapping of the character.
This argument receives the CharType column from the embedded CSV file.

This value is the CharacterSubtype enumeration mapping of the character.
This argument receives the Subtype column from the embedded CSV file.

This value is the standard two or three character acronymn for the character, including the square brackets that usually enclose it. This value is meaningful only for the Control Characters group. This value is blank for all others.
This argument receives the CHAR column from the embedded CSV file.

When appropriate, this field returns a short text description of the character.
This argument receives the DESCRIPTION column from the embedded CSV file.

This field returns the HTML entity name, when one exists, of the character, its HTML entity string.
This argument receives the HTML Name column from the embedded CSV file.

Specify alternate text to display in place of the actual character.
This argument receives the Display column from the embedded CSV file.

Specify a comment for optional display on listings.
This argument receives the Comment column from the embedded CSV file.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.ASCIICharacter
member.summary: Gets the Unicode character represented by the code

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.AlternateText
member.summary: Gets an alternative visual representation of certain nonprintable and otherwise ambiguous characters, such as the SPACE character.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CHAR
member.summary: This value is the standard two or three character acronymn for the character, including the square brackets that usually enclose it. This value is meaningful only for the Control Characters group. This value is blank for all others.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharType
member.summary: Gets the CharacterType enumeration mapping of the character

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CharSubType
member.summary: Gets the CharacterSubtype enumeration mapping of the character

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.Code
member.summary: Gets the unsigned integer representation of the ASCII code

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CodeAsDecimal
member.summary: Gets a string representation of the raw ASCII code as a decimal number, formatted to always occupy the maximum number of characters needed, three

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.CodeAsHexadecimal
member.summary: Gets a string representation of the ASCII code as a hexadecimal number

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.UnicodeCodePoint
member.summary: Gets a string representation of the Unicode code point

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.Comment
member.summary: Gets the associated comment, if one exists, or returns the empty string.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.Description
member.summary: When appropriate, this field returns a short text description of the character.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.DisplayText
member.summary: Use this property to guarantee that any character will display something useful when the character is presented on its own, out of context, such as in an error message.
member.remarks: The objective of this property is to return something that is always acceptable in printed matter, without surprises such as line feeds, line wraps, and page ejects, among other things elicited by some of the control codes.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.HTMLName
member.summary: This field returns the HTML entity name, when one exists, of the character, its HTML entity string. Otherwise, the return value is the empty string, represented herein by a true constant, SpecialStrings.EMPTY_STRING.
member.remarks: If this returns anything besides the empty string, the string returned by this property should probably take its place in HTML text.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.URLEncoding
member.summary: Gets the URLEncoding value of the character, which is available for ANY character, though it is needed only for punctuation, control codes, white space, and other special characters

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.ToString
member.summary: Override ToString to render all three defined formats and most other properties.
member.returns: The return value is a string containing a printable representation of the character, followed by its hexadecimal and decimal values, both enclosed in a single pair of parenetheses, then by every conceivable way to represent the character except the URL encoding, which can be inferred from the hexadecimal string inserted as the CodeAsHexadecimal property value.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.DisplayCharacterInfo(System.Char)
member.summary: Create a ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo instance to represent a specified ASCII character, and call its ToString method to return all three representations of it (Printable, Hexadecimal, and Decimal, in that order.
member.param: Specify the character for which to render the three representations.
member.returns: Return the output of ToString on the ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.ASCII_Character_Display_Table
member.summary: Provide read only access to a table of ASCII characters and text to display for selected special characters.
member.example:
The ASCII code for a space is 32. ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo[32], for C#, or ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo(32), for Visual Basic, returns the item for the space character.
Likewise, the ASCII code for a horizontal TAB character is 9. Hence, the C# expression ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo[9] evaluates to the information about the TAB character. Likewise, ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo(9) does the same thing in Visual Basic.
The following example comes from production code in the class library that motivated me to create this library.
ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo [ ] asciiCharTbl = ASCII_Character_Display_Table.GetTheSingleInstance ( ).AllASCIICharacters; StringBuilder sbTheBadChar = new StringBuilder ( ); sbTheBadChar.Append ( asciiCharTbl [ ( uint ) _chrBad ].DisplayText );
Obviously, more things go into the message before it is returned to the calling routine.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ASCII_Character_Display_Table.GetTheSingleInstance
member.summary: Gets a reference to the single ASCII_Character_Display_Table instance.
member.returns: The return value is a reference to the single instance of this class that is created in response to the first call to this method. Please see the remarks.
member.remarks:
The example given under the help topic for this class shows you that you need not actually allocate storage for the instance, since what you really need is a copy of the ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo table, available through the read only AllASCIICharacters property, which can be assigned directly to an AllASCIICharacters array.
To preserve its independence, this class uses the archaic Singleton implementation, rather than inherit from the abstract base class in WizardWrx.DllServices2.dll, although I could certainly fix that by linking the source code into this assembly. Since that creates an even more awkward dependency, and I don't want to put an actual copy in this source tree, I'll leave it alone. After all, this class is not exactly a high traffic property.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ASCII_Character_Display_Table.AllASCIICharacters
member.summary: Gets the populated ASCIICharacterDisplayInfo array that is the sole public property of this class, which exists to ensure that exactly one instance of this table exists.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ASCII_Character_Display_Table.InitialzeInstance
member.summary: Since the class is a singleton, I separated the initializer from the constructor, as has been my custom.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ASCII_Character_Display_Table._asciiTable
member.summary: It all comes down to this little array.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark
member.summary: Use this class to evaluate arbitrary byte arrays for the presence of a Byte Order Mark.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType
member.summary: Members of this enumeration report the type of byte order mark, if any, present at its beginning.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.None
member.summary: The array has no Byte Order Mark.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UTF8
member.summary: The array has a UTF-8 Byte Order Mark.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UTF16LE
member.summary: The array has a UTF-16 Byte Order Mark that indicates little-endian character encoding.
member.remarks: The little-endian encoding is the native encoding of the entire Intel processor family and its clones (e. g., AMD).

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UTF16BE
member.summary: The array has a UTF-16 Byte Order Mark that indicates big-endian character encoding.
member.remarks: The big-endian encoding is the native encoding of the MIPS Alpha family of processors, among others.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UnicodeLittleEndian
member.summary: UnicodeLittleEndian is a synonym of UTF16LE, the encoding that corresponds to the wide character encoding on Microsoft Windows.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UnicodeBigEndian
member.summary: UnicodeLittleEndian is a synonym of UTF16BE, the encoding that corresponds to the wide character encoding on Microsoft Windows, running on a big-endian processor, which MAY include code that runs on ARM processors.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UTF32LE
member.summary: The array has a UTF-32 Byte Order Mark that indicates little-endian character encoding.
member.remarks: This seldom-used encoding is defined for completeness, and in anticipation of its usage increasing.

member.name: F:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.BOMType.UTF32BE
member.summary: The array has a UTF-32 Byte Order Mark that indicates big-endian character encoding.
member.remarks: This seldom-used encoding is defined for completeness, and in anticipation of its usage increasing.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.#ctor(System.Byte[])
member.summary: The only internal constructor demands a reference to the byte array to evaluate.
member.param: Supply a reference to the byte array to test for a Byte Order Mark.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.Kind
member.summary: This read-only property returns the type of Byte Order Mark present in the byte array that was supplied to the constructor.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.Length
member.summary: This read-only property returns the length of the Byte Order Mark.
member.remarks: Since the property is initialized on first use, it may display an invalid value of -1 in a watch window.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.ByteOrderMark.TestForBOM
member.summary: If it hasn't been directly called, the first call to either property getter calls this method, so that the work required to evaluate the array for a byte order mark is deferred until it is needed, and it is never subsequently repeated for the lifetime of the instance.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.Readers
member.summary: This static class exposes methods for loading text from custom resources that are embedded in an assembly.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.Readers.LoadTextFileFromCallingAssembly(System.String)
member.summary: Load the lines of a plain ASCII text file that has been stored with the assembly as a embedded resource into an array of native strings.
member.param: Specify the absolute (fully qualified) resource name, which is its source file name appended to the default assembly namespace.
member.returns: The return value is an array of Unicode strings, each of which is the text of a line from the original text file, sans terminator.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.Readers.LoadTextFileFromAnyAssembly(System.String,System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Load the lines of a plain ASCII text file that has been stored with a specified assembly as a embedded resource into an array of native strings.
member.param: Specify the absolute (fully qualified) resource name, which is its source file name appended to the default assembly namespace name.
Pass in a reference to the Assembly from which you expect to load the text file. Use any means at your disposal to obtain a reference from the System.Reflection namespace.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.Readers.LoadBinaryResourceFromAnyAssembly(System.String,System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Load the named embedded binary resource into a byte array.
member.param: Specify the external name of the file as it appears in the source file tree and the Solution Explorer.
Supply a System.Reflection.Assembly reference to the assembly that contains the embedded resource.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, it returns a byte array containing the raw bytes that comprise the embedded resource. Hence, this method can load ANY embedded resource.
member.remarks:
Since all other resource types ultimately come out as byte arrays, the text file loaders call upon this routine to extract their data.
The notes in the cited reference refreshed my memory of observations that I made and documented a couple of weeks ago. However, it was a lot easier to let Google find a reference document, which was intended for students in the Computer Science department at Columbia University, at http://www1.cs.columbia.edu/~lok/csharp/refdocs/System.IO/types/Stream.html"/>, than find my own source.
member.exception: An Exception (the base Exception type) arises when the method is called with a value that cannot be found in the assembly. When the exception arises during the read operation, the generic Exception wraps an InvalidDataException exception, which is returned as its InnnerException property.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.Readers.StringFromANSICharacterArray(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Transform an array of bytes, each representing one ANSI character, into a string.
member.param: Specify the array to transform.
member.returns: The array is returned as a string.
member.remarks: I did this refactoring, thinking that I had a new use for the code, only to realize as I finished cleaning it up that I can't use it, because it deals in ANSI characters, and my present need involves Unicode characters. Nevertheless, the exercise is not a total loss, because it reminded me of the trick that I needed to transform the array of Unicode characters into a string.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.Readers.StringOfLinesToArray(System.String,System.StringSplitOptions)
member.summary: Split a string containing lines of text into an array of strings, as modified by the StringSplitOptions flag.
member.param: String containing lines of text, terminated by CR/LF pairs.

A member of the StringSplitOptions enumeration, presumably other than StringSplitOptions.None, which is assumed by the first overload. The only option supported by version 2 of the Microsoft .NET CLR is RemoveEmptyEntries.
member.returns: Array of strings, one line per string. Blank lines are preserved as empty strings unless penmStringSplitOptions is RemoveEmptyEntries, as is most likely to be the case.
member.remarks: Use this overload to convert a string, discarding blank lines.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.Readers.StringToArray(System.String)
member.summary: Return a one-element array containing the input string.
member.param: String to place into the returned array.
member.returns: Array of strings, containing exactly one element, which contains the single input string.

member.name: M:WizardWrx.Readers.GetInternalResourceName(System.String,System.Reflection.Assembly)
member.summary: Use the list of Manifest Resource Names returned by method GetManifestResourceNames on a specified assembly. Each of several methods employs a different mechanism to identify the assembly of interest.
member.param: Specify the name of the file from which the embedded resource was created. Typically, this will be the local name of the file in the source code tree.
Pass a reference to the Assembly that is supposed to contain the desired resource.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the internal name of the requested resource, which is fed to GetManifestResourceStream on the same assembly, which returns a read-only Stream backed by the embedded resource. If the specified resource is not found, it returns null.
member.remarks: Since I cannot imagine any use for this method beyond its infrastructure role in this class, I marked it private.

member.name: T:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources
member.summary: A strongly-typed resource class, for looking up localized strings, etc.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources.ResourceManager
member.summary: Returns the cached ResourceManager instance used by this class.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources.Culture
member.summary: Overrides the current thread's CurrentUICulture property for all resource lookups using this strongly typed resource class.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources.DISPLAY_TEMPLATE
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Code = {0} (Hex = {1}), Character Type = {2}, Character Subtype = {3}, Unicode Display {4}, Alternate Display = {5}, HTML Entity Name = {6}, Control Code Acronymn {7}, Description = {8}, Comment = {9}.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_BAD_DETAIL_ROW
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Internal Table Error: Detaill row {0} is invalid.{3}Expected field count = {1}{3}Actaul field count = {2}.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_BAD_LABEL_ROW
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Internal Table Error: The label row is invalid.{2}Expected label row = {0}{2}Actaul label row = {1}.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_CHAR_CODE_OUT_OF_RANGE
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Character code {0} is out of range. It must be between {1} and {2}..

member.name: P:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_EMBEDDED_RESOURCE_NOT_FOUND
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Resource {0} cannot be found in assembly {1}..

member.name: P:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_EMBEDDED_RESOURCE_READ_ERROR
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to An error occurred while reading data from resources embedded in an assembly.{3}Assembly Full Name = {0}{3}Internal Resource Name = {1}{3}I/O Error Message = {2}{3}{3}The associated Inner Exception may contain additional clues..

member.name: P:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_EMBEDDED_RESOURCE_READ_TRUNCATED
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to An error occurred while reading a file from resources embedded in an assembly.{3}Internal Name = {0}{3}Expected File Length (bytes) = {1}{3}Bytes successfully read = {2}.

member.name: P:WizardWrx.Properties.Resources.ERRMSG_UNEXPECTED_ROW_COUNT
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to Internal Table Error: The ASCII Table should contain {0} rows. Instead, it contains {1} rows..
